text: [MUSIC PLAYING]

She had no background
in science or business,

but within a few
years at Polaroid,

she rose to become
manager of black and white

photographic research,
and then director

of special
photographic research.

She oversaw increasing numbers
of employees, whose well-being
and advancement she fostered.

Many remember her humor,
self-effacing nature,

quiet reserve, and
steely determination.

The Polaroid Corporation,
founded by Edwin Land,
was incorporated in 1937.

The company produced
synthetic sheet polarizers

for sunglass lenses, camera
filters, and desk lamps.

During World War II, Polaroid
contracted with the US Military

to produce polarizing filters
for a range of products,

such as binoculars,
periscopes, and goggles.

It was in 1948 that Land
introduced instant photography.

Meroë Morse was an
inspiring figure

when the numbers of women
who held jobs in industry

had decreased dramatically,
as men returning

from World War II
reclaimed their positions
in the workforce.

At Polaroid, however, there
were progressive policies
to hire women.

Morse worked
throughout the 1950s

and '60s on the advancement
of black and white films.

Her laboratory succeeded
in producing faster films

with greater tonal
range and brilliance.

She oversaw round-the-clock
shifts of researchers conducting

thousands of experiments,
and met increasing demands

for new Polaroid films,
as the popularity
of instant photography soared.

Morse also played a significant
role as company liaison

to Ansel Adams, who reviewed
technical and design aspects
of Polaroid cameras and films.

The archives is filled with
thousands of memos and test
photographs taken by Adams.

When Meroë Morse majored in
Art History at Smith College,

she studied under
Clarence Kennedy,

professor of Renaissance
History and also
a consultant to Polaroid.

So while Land hired individuals
trained in physics, chemistry,

and optics, he also valued those
with humanities backgrounds,

and he began to recruit
Kennedy's students
to work at Polaroid.

Edwin Land cultivated a
distinctly creative culture,

an interdisciplinary
community that

was devoted to the technical
and artistic excellence
of the new photographic medium.

Like Land, Morse
understood Polaroid

from the multiple lenses
of business, science, art,
and humanity.

As the company grew,
she, in essence,

assumed the role
of a chief advisor

to the CEO of a major
corporation at a time

when the responsibilities
of C-suite executives

were held almost
exclusively by men.
